superlatives we are using them to

of something a superlative can be one

word
or a combination of words in a sentence

so when we use superlatives
we are describing the highest quality

of something now when we say quality
it can mean anything that describes that

certain
aspect the appearance the shape

the way it works the way it moves
the color the lightness

the brightness the darkness
so superlatives always go for the

or quality of something and a

superlative

so we can describe something in a

and we are also showing that that thing

in the english language there are
many ways of describing the highest

quality of something the highest point
of something the thing that is

at its very best
and this lesson will help you work out

how
they are used

hi everybody this is mr duncan in
england how

are you today are you okay i hope so
are you happy i hope so

today we are going to look at a part of
english grammar

that expresses the very best and worst
of things we see

and do the clearest way to express
what is the greatest in fact i'm doing

it now
as i make this introduction today

we are going to look at those super
duper
superlatives

a superlative is a form of grammar that
expresses

the highest degree of equality to say
that something is better than all the

rest
is to use a superlative sentence

individual words can convey a
superlative expression

superlatives come in many different
forms

they are often formed as words ending in
est

or with the word most a superlative can
be used to show that

something is hard to beat or that its
quality

or performance is for the time being
difficult to match

a superlative can be formed and appear
in many ways if a person does something

that no one else has
then a superlative can be used to

describe
what has been achieved the best

or the greatest would be suitable words
to use in this case

the greatest athlete the best
swimmer the strongest man or woman

on the track a superlative can be used
in a certain time period

such as a day that was the fastest race
today

she is the best singer i have heard
today

in these sentences we are showing that
the superlative

only relates to the event on the day
being the best today means that tomorrow

there might be someone just as good or
even better

when we say that something is good
then we are stating that it is

acceptable
it is not bad it is good

it is passable it is okay
it is sufficient it is satisfactory

many things are good the quality of
something

such as meat can be described as good
however it is possible to describe

something as being best if it has been
recognized in some way

if something has been awarded a prize
or a high grade then best

can be used in 2012
he won an award for being the best

butcher
in england once again this superlative

is relevant to the time in which it was
given

being the best one year does not mean
you will be voted the best
the next year

let's take a look at some examples of
superlatives

great greatest
good best

high highest
clean cleanest

bright brightest
new newest latest

brave bravest
wealthy wealthiest

clever cleverest
amazing most amazing

exciting most exciting
difficult most difficult
expensive most expensive

familiar most familiar
memorable most memorable

enjoyable most enjoyable
stunning most stunning

in english the superlative can be used
in a way that suggests something

that is not strictly so superlatives can
be used

figuratively they suggest something for
effect

for example the most complete collection
of modern art in england

does not mean that all modern art is
contained there

the sentence seems to be saying this but
in fact

it is not so certain words have been
brought into common use

as superlatives contemporary writing
often places a superlative here and

there
so as to add excitement or draw

attention
superlatives are often used in

advertising
we might sometimes use the word

superlative to show that something
is unique overwhelming or

insurmountable in quality or form
there are not enough superlatives to

describe this show
the film critics lavished superlatives

on her performance
by this you are showing that something

has left you feeling
overwhelmed and impressed

we sometimes play with words to show a
superlative that is not real

a common one is bestest
which of course is not a real word but

can be used as a fun way of showing
how much something means to you you are

my
bestest friend in the whole world

another one is awesomest this is not a
real word

but it can be used informally to show
that
in your opinion something is the best

it is possible to use most as a way of
expressing that something

or someone has impressed you or has
left an impression on you that meal

was most satisfying i had a most
enjoyable evening that lecture you gave

was most interesting
we found the most delightful place to

have a picnic
she speaks in the most eloquent way

superlatives can be used to show the
most extreme things

both positively and negatively
the most positive thing is the best

while the most negative thing is the
worst

the extremes of bad include the coldest
day the smelliest cheese

our darkest hour the saddest song
the moodiest person the loneliest
man the bleakest forecast

we often make a note of things that
exist as

unique or unbeatable the tallest
building

the fastest runner the largest bowl of
custard

the cleverest man and all the other
things worthy of note

we call these things records
anything that cannot be beaten or is the

most
will be recorded the facts surrounding

this event
or thing are written down

you can be the fastest runner in england
or the fastest runner in the world

most people aim for a world record
they want to be the best the greatest

the tallest even the shortest
or the oldest is worthy of being

included
in the list of world records but of

course
just like many other superlatives many

of these records
can be beaten eventually

when the oldest living man in the world
dies

the second oldest takes his place
the tallest building in the world now

might not be
in a couple of years time that

particular record
could be broken

superlatives are great for showing how
good or bad

something is even if they are not
absolutely true

your worst day ever might be tomorrow
but it may also be next tuesday

we often throw superlatives into a
sentence

for effect superlatives are
dramatic they are expressive

they effectively express extremes
both an action and emotion

the best of the best and the worst of
the worst

are often used to show how great or
awful

something is but it is not necessarily
definitive or permanent what might

seem the best or worse today can change
as time goes by

what could be better than a day at the
sea

what could be better than you with me
what could be finer than a day in bed

what could be better than cheese and
bread

what could be nicer than a card from mum
what could be sweeter than a

sugar-coated bun
what could be better than the kindness

of a friend
what could be greater than a love that

has no
end

lesson two sentences part one
present simple questions questions in

the present simple
with be are formed by swapping the verb

and subject for other verbs the
auxiliary verb

do or does must be added before the
subject

questions with b in the present simple
to form questions in the present simple

using be
reverse the order of the subject and the

verb
for example you are

canadian are you
canadian how to form

present simple questions you have
the form of be am is

are you have the subject
i he she

it you we
they and the rest of the sentence

am i canadian
is he canadian is

she canadian is it canadian
are you canadian are we
canadian are they canadian

further examples include am i on time
is he your brother where

are we am i on the list
is it time to leave are they friendly

questions with do and does
for questions with verbs other than be

start the question with
do or does don't swap the subject

and the main verb you work
in an office becomes
do you work in an office

she works in a school becomes
does she work in a school

how to form this sentence
you have the form of do and does

you have the subject i
you we they

he she it
you have the base form of the verb

work the verb never takes
s or e s when you ask a question

then you have the rest of the sentence
do i work in an office

do you work in an office
do we work in an office

do they work in an office
does he work in an office

does she work in an office
does it work in an office further

examples
do they live in paris

do you usually finish work at 4 pm
does tom get up at 6am

when does the party start question words
can be used before

do or does to form open questions
common mistakes forming present simple

questions
never add s or e s to the base form of

the verb when asking a question
even in the third person singular

such as he she or it
does he finish work on time

correct does he finish his work
on time incorrect

part two the present continuous
the present continuous is used to talk

about continued
actions that are happening in the

present moment
it is formed with be and a present

participle
an example of the present continuous

the present continuous is used to
describe a current

continued action julie
usually wears jeans but today

she is wearing a dress
the word wears is the present simple

it describes a repeated action or
situation

she is this is the present continuous
use

of the verb be wearing
this is the present continuous it

describes what is happening
right now how to form the present

continuous you have the subject
she you have the form of

am is are
is you have the verb

ending with i n g
the present participle for example

wearing and then the rest of the
sentence

address she is wearing
a dress further examples

we are walking the dog he is washing
the dishes they are talking on their

phones
they're fighting with each other she's

relaxing at the moment it's raining a
lot

outside present
participle spelling rules

the present participle is formed by
adding

i n g to the base form of the verb
some participles have slightly different

spelling rules
for example where becomes

wearing choose
becomes choosing tie

becomes tying
shop becomes shopping

further examples they're opening the
store next week

there is no need to double the last
letter because the final syllable

is not stressed harry
is always lying to his mother i'm

cutting some apples
my uncle is writing a novel

terry is mopping the floor
my mother is baking as a cake

here is a useful tip present participles
follow the same spelling rules as

gerunds
common mistakes to state verbs

in continuous tenses
action verbs can be used in simple and

continuous form state verbs are not
usually used

in continuous forms in
action i read every day

correct i am reading right now
correct as a state

i own two cars correct
i am owning two cars

incorrect questions in the present
continuous

to ask questions in the present
continuous swap the subject

and the form of be he
is playing tennis

as a question is he playing tennis
he is the subject

this action is happening right now
is he playing tennis you are asking

if someone is doing a certain thing
right now how to form

the sentence you have the form
of am is are

is you have the subject
he you have the verb

plus ing playing
and then you have the rest of the

sentence
tennis

further examples include are they going
to the park

is he cycling to work is she
eating pizza are they working late

where are we going today are you coming
to the party

what are you eating for dinner is it
raining outside

question words such as what where and
how

can be used before the verb to form
open questions where

are we going today this is an open
question the present continuous negative

he is wearing a tie but he is not

you have the subject he
you have the form of am

is are not
